gute Spielwelt

I played this game back when it first came out on the xbox 360, and picked it up a while ago. Even though the voice acting is terrible, the character models awful, and the over all interface is very clunky; the game is really fun. Combat isnt as impressive either but the exploration aspect and the sights are really cool. 

If you can look past its age, it will provide multiple hours of entertainment and if you are an RPG lover then this game is a must to cross of your list.
10/10 would dodge again

First of all, I have played through the whole original game on console.. That said, It was and is , maybe my favorite RPGs I have ever played, besides  Divinity II and Dark Messiah, Yes the story is somewhat cliche, but it's the Journey not the end that matters (The ending is good though)  And some might say the combat and the voice acting are terrible, but imo it's what give it its charm and I love it, esp the voice acting, everything is voice acted, a somewhat rarity. And now there is this version with (0! holy..90?! new quests, I'ma be gettin' down. If you wanna "Get away" this is deff it, super atmospheric and immersive to the core, and the music is amazing. Syrim could take lessons from this (And prolly did)  It's like su8mmer in Skyrim old school, since I know every1 compares everything to Skyrim... Oblivion was better. ;)

Oh and Two Worlds > Two World 2, if you are debating a buy.  (imo)

This is an old game that i have played across console and PC. Its a rich RPG that even after picking up the games years later I am still able to get full immersed in the land and lore. If you can get past the dated graphics in my opinion this is one of the best RPGs out there for its time on par with TES4 Oblivion.
Great classic with a Dark Souls like emphasis on evading hits rather than tanking them. Unique for it's time CCG magic system.
klimat

Do you have an unmitigated hatred of wolves, boars and bandits?  If so, my friend, this is your game!  

To be honest, this is less an RPG than it is a wildlife murder simulator, but the only real crime that is committed in this game is done by the voice actors.  Wow.

Truthfully, the game has it's charms, and it can be fun, but I reached my limit.  If you like open world games with mindless combat than this might do.  If you prefer deeper game mechanics, story, and lore then you are definitely going to want to look elsewhere.

Its a rather fun game. It takes a bit to get into and there are a few things here and there but it is a rather nice game. It does show its age a little in terms of graphics but for those that can look past that it is a good game. The combat is rather simplistic but almost remincaint of old school MMOs in a way if you ask me. 

Quick sidenote for Mac users, Im currently running High Serria and orginally bought this game for my Mac. It would run for me but only up to the menu, when I went to start the game it would crash on me. Its just a small side note, for all intesive purposes I was attempting to run it off of a 6 year old laptop thats been used practically everyday within those 6 years so that could be part of the problem but I thought it would be something that should be mentioned up front just in case.

Machen wir uns nichts vor: ein Meisterwerk ist das Ganze nun nicht gerade, und die vielen Bugs und Unzulänglichkeiten sind in anderen Bewertungen hinreichend beschrieben worden. 

Als netter Zeitvertreib, wenn man wie ich nur einen Schrottcomputer hat, taugt das Ganze aber allemal. Außerdem ist die Spielmusik (von Harold Faltermayer; ja, genau dem von Axel F und so) wirklich sehr gelungen und macht einiges wett.

Jest git ale TwoWorlds II lepsze

Jelikož jsem prvně hrál druhý díl, který mě absolutně uchvátil a posléze vyčkával kdy bude první díl v Epic Edition ve slevě. Netrvalo dlouho a než jsem druhý díl dohrál rozehrál jsem díl první abych plně porozuměl světu a příběhu. Musím říct že hned od začátku jsem byl udiven že první díl je v pár klíčových věcech, které mě na této hře ohromili velmi odlišný i přesto mě první díl také okouzlil. Bohužel poznačen druhým dílem se neubráním pár srovnání a nechci zde popisovat co je ve druhém díle lepší a proto za nějaké poznatky a výtky přidám pouze značku (2), která naznačuje že ve druhém díle je odlišnost.

Hned samotný začátek hry a tím myslím menu hry je velmi odlišné od druhého dílu a musím říct že k lepšímu druhý díl má menu poněkud … zvláštní nesedící ke stylizaci celé hry takže zde první díl vede. Druhá a velmi příjemná zpráva je že oba díly jsou s plnou podporou češtiny v textové podobě. Celé menu dialogy a titulky k cut scénám je v češtině a to velmi potěší. Do třetice hned v úvodním menu zní krásná vážná (operní) hudba. Do které se zaposloucháte a po delší době při kochání se výhledem na krajinu se najednou hudba promění do metalu  v podobě kapely Witch Temple a to opravdu já ocením.

Po dlouhé editaci postavy, která je stejně jedno protože v cut scénách je default postava a po celou dobu hry máte stejně přilbu, takže vyhožený čas nad vytvářením postavy stejně jak v ostatních hrách kde můžete svou postavu editovat až příliš.

Jste vhozeni do obrovského světa jehož hranice od počátku znáte (2). Myslím tím že víte kudy vede cesta kde je jaký město atd..  ale objevit kde je jaký portál jeskyně kupec nebo úkol musíte dojít sami a mapa se postupně mění ze zašedlé na jasnou na místech kde jste již byli. Máte absolutní volnost můžete se sbalit a přejít na druhý konec mapy a do jakékoliv města. Pochybuji že se vám to povede protože celá země je pokryta nepřáteli lupiči, zvířata, mystické bytosti, nemrtví atd… Takže myšlenka že by jste došli dál než do vedlejší vesnice je docela úsměvná ale je to správně jak budete objevovat a plnit mise po mapě bude vaše postava sílit a tím se budete moct probojovat na další části mapy. Musím říct že síla je poměrně dobře rozložena tím je vaše cestování přirozeně omezeno ale můžete jako já zamířit zrovna do místa kde jsou ty nejsilnější zlé bytosti a pokusit se nějakou porazit a po hodině odskakování a ubírání života po milimetru prásk jednou ranou odpálen přes půl mapy od golema, který je dvakrát tak vysoký a asi dvacetkrát silnější než vy. Takže pokud tuto hru ne chcete hrát století se stejně na vrátíte do míst kde jsou vám plus mínus sobě rovni.

Trochu k příběhu ten by se ve výsledku dal shrnout asi pěti větami to ale nevadí jelikož zde jde hlavně o cestu která vede ke konci příběhu a ta cesta je opravdu dlooooooháááááá. Jste potomek z urozené rodiny avšak celé svého dědictví a moci jste se vzdali z jistých důvodu a to především z toho že chcete být vlastním pánem svého osudu a nebýt loutkou bohů a rodu starších. Hledáte místo kde byste se mohli se svou sestrou usadit a žít spokojený život a však vaše sestra byla unesena. Únosci po vás vyžadují aby jste objevili a získali pro ně starověké magické relikty. Jenom vy to můžete dokázat protože jste právě potomky rodu jenž je určen k velkým věcem a nikdo jiný než vy to nedokáže jelikož sestru drží jako rukojmí. Tato zápletka vás donutí projít prakticky celou mapu křížem krážem a plnit úkoly aby jste získali informace kde se tito relikty ukrývají. Po cestách potkáte spoustu zajímavých stvoření a postav, které vás seznámí s celou historií vašeho národu a všech ostatních národů a stvoření. Dost mi to připomíná Gothic 3 s tím že zde ale víte od začátku co je váš hlavní cíl.

Soubojový systém je prakticky složen ze dvou tlačítek útok a úskok. Celý boj je kostrbaty takže nečekejte žádné složitosti i zda mi to dost připomíná Gothic. Můžete zvolit z několika bojových stylů kde se to dá rozdělit na tři hlavní boj se zbraní, s lukem, s magií. Tady začíná rozdíl mezi jedničkou a dvojkou očividný. V této sérii jsem se rozhodl hrát s lukem bohužel v tomto dílu je to utrpení. Než natáhnu luk jsem mrtví (2+), když budete sledovat jak střílí vaší nepřátelé tak se jedná o sérii uteč co nejdál pak zaměřuj půl hodiny a doufej že se trefíš to není pro mě. Druhý je magie (2+), která hraje v této sérii velkou roli ale nedostal jsem se do stavu kdy bych pomocí bojových kouzel ubral nepříteli výrazné množství zdraví. Tím pádem jsem skončil u mečů a pak kvůli lepšímu brnění jsem byl donucen přejít na meč se štítem. Ale stále jsem byl velmi magicky založený.

Velkým zklamáním je vyvoláváním uznávám že mám slabost pro zakázané kouzla nekromancie ale když jsem se dočetl že můžu vyvolat vlastního satana a dokonce Pána Pekel tak jsem vše investoval do magie ohně. Bohužel Pán Pekel netrefí ani stodolu. Zkoušel jsem to jako velmistr nekromancie můžu zadržet pomocí hrobní magie protivníka na místě dokud neutrží poranění velmi užitečné v boji proti mnohem silnějšímu protivníkovy. Takže tam ten Golem velký jak stodola stojí a Pán Pekel se nemůže trefit. To není problém jen této postavy většina vyvolaných stvoření má stejný problém jediný, který se mi osvědčil byl škorpión a stvoření s lukem.

Magie je tvořena kartami ty můžete různě kombinovat s kartami vylepšení a docílit silného kouzla delší doba vyvolání, nižší spotřeba many, silnější poškození atd… Čím víc karet daného kouzla máte tím silnější kouzlo je. To platí i u předmětů pokud naleznete více stejných mečů nebo vybavení vytvoříte z nich jeden předmět a ten je patřičně silný tento mechanismus shromažďování se mi velmi líbí. Víc tu popisovat nebudu protože už teď povykládám manuál.

Mohu prozradit že hlavní příběh [spoiler]je lineární a jak naznačuje název i zde jsou dva konce naštěstí se konec rozhoduje jen poslední misí, kterou jste schopni dohrát cca do 10 minut. To vše opravdu nevadí protože celá hra je tvořena právě poutí, která vede ke konci hry a během cest můžete svými činy opravdu ovlivnit chod ve světě  a vývoj událostí i když většinou jen okrajově. [/spoiler]

[b]TIP[/b] Pokud vás v boji odzbrojí prvně zvedněte tyto předměty ze země než použijete protože tyto předměty po teleportu zmizí jako jediný.

[b]+[/b] Systém vylepšování předmětů.
[b]+[/b] Magie a systém karet (2+).
[b]+[/b] Semi lineární příběh. Myslím tím že začátek a konce jsou stejný ale cestu a rozhodnutí komu jak pomoct je na vás.
[b]+[/b] Lokace, různé vegetace na mapě poušť, prales, vypálený lest atd…
[b]+[/b] Kira… prostě vypadá jako metalová s e x y princezna takže vás to opravdu motivuje ji zachránit. Takže… Kira!
[b]+[/b] Koně hlavně nemrtví kůň.
[b]+[/b] Systém teleportace a rozmístění oltářů.
[b]+[/b] Hra je připravena na hraní ve 4k. Tím myslím že celé rozhraní zachová velikost textu a oken takže žádné malé blechy na monitoru. Krásné velké texty stejně jako při Full HD hraní otestováno.
[b]+[/b] Obří svět a zajímavé stvoření.
[b]+[/b] Alchymie tvoří velkou část hry ale lze ji nahradit tím že si předměty začnete kupovat.

[b]#[/b] Cca po hodině docházelo k pádu hry. Zřejmě zato mohly auto savi. Kompletně zápis na disk hru zasekl na pár sekund.
[b]#[/b] Některé mise se mi podařilo zablokovat že nešli dokončit ja úspěchem nebo neúspěchem. Nebo se mi zamkla možnost dohrát tuto misi neutrálně.
[b]#[/b] Hudba je opravdu zajímavá. Mám rád že se snaží být jiná než ostatní hry. Velkou část tvoří klasická hudba, která má zakomponovanou metal žánr ale je tu i motiv z 80. let a to trochu kazí za mě dojem jinak velmi povedený.

[b]-[/b] Boj s lukem mi připadá velmi špatný.
[b]-[/b] Pouze dvě kouzla v medailon mohou využít bonusové karty ke kouzlu. Pokud jednu pozici medailonu sdílí víc jak jedno kouzlo jsou po použití dvou odlišných kozel bonusové karty z této pozice v medailonu odstraněny a nemají účinek.
[b]-[/b] Kolem levelu 50 přestanou padat silnější nebo stejně silné předměty.
[b]-[/b] Záseky ve hře při větších bojích.

Staroszkolny erpeg, który wygląda znacznie gorzej niż się w niego gra. System walki jest prosty, wręcz prostacki, ale system lootu i kolejne połacie mapy utrzymały mnie przy grze ponad 60 godzin, a to o czymś świadczy. Uprzedzam od razu - fabuła jest  nieprzyzwoicie pretekstowa, zakończenie jest rozczarowujące, a voice actingu nie da się słuchać. W ogóle muzyka jest jakaś opcjonalna. Jeśli ktoś chce popykać i pozabijać monstra bez większych przemyśleń, a zakochany jest w grach z okolicy 2000 roku - polecam. Jeśli jednak szukasz gry życia a najważniejsza jest historia to lepiej omiń ją szerokim łukiem.
YUCK!

Allora, diciamo subito che questa recensione è frutto di due discorsi insieme: da un parte c'è, ovviamente, l'effetto nostalgia e la considerazione del gioco all'epoca che uscì (quest'edizione è del 2009). All'epoca già sembrò, giustamente, a moltissimi un'occasione persa di fare un giocone con delle ottime premesse che poi, come spesso accade, vennero disattese con grande dispiacere degli appassionati del genere GDR action. Però i suoi lati positivi li aveva come la grafica, il loot, il crafting, la possibilità d'incantare armi e armature, scegliere cosa diventare sviluppando comunque anche tutte le abilità volendo, missioni secondarie, ciclo giorno/notte con relative difficoltà, reputazioni con alcune fazioni, combattimenti a cavallo. Ma se partiamo da questo è facile capire perchè Two Worlds sia rimasto un'opera incompiuta: dialoghi assolutamente inespressivi (a volte gli NPC manco aprono la bocca) ed inutili, movimenti del protagonista ai limiti dell'umana comprensione, trama che non trascina, grafica bella si ma dando l'impressione di essere in un mondo finto (bellino da vicino ma nullo in lontananza), combattimenti ridicoli, nessuna indicazione chiara di dove andare per fare le quest secondarie (fondamentale in un RPG), il fatto dello sviluppo anche per console si vede tantissimo, ciclo giorno/notte solo apparente perchè poi le differenze sono quasi nulle (tranne che per alcuni fantasmi che s'incontrano per la via...). 
In conclusione l'amarezza fu tanta. Se vi aspettate un GDR action stile primo Gothic assolutamente no; se vi accontentate di un clone riuscito male di Gothic 3 allora si. Voto 5...ci gioco solo per nostalgia.

[u][b] A Cynical Review: Two Worlds – Epic Edition [/b][/u]

[b] Is There A Plot?: [/b]
There is a plot… but with the “great” voice acting it is pretty hard to stay interested. It did come out in 2007 but so did Bioshock 1, Mass Effect 1, Crysis, Halo 3, The Witcher 1… you get the idea.

[b] Is This Even Fun?: [/b]
This game has an incredibly large open world, and gives off ES4-Oblivion vibes. The equipment upgrading system is pretty cool as well, using multiple copies of the same item to level them up. Just do not try riding horses… The Epic Edition has remastered certain aspects of the game, most notably being the graphics. They are not great, but have hyper detailed textures which is surprisingly nice.  

[b] Is It Worth Buying?: [/b]
This game is niche. In this day and age, unless you have previously played Two Worlds and want to see how the Epic Edition has “remastered” things, the average gamer will probably not enjoy this. But it is usually on sale and fairly cheap, so if you are looking for a campy open world RPG to check out this is your game. 

[b] 6/10 [/b]

This is a classic! Super campy dialogue, wonky animations, and bugs, but if you don't mind that stuff, this game is wonderful! Deep customization in equipment, crafting, amazing magic and a variety of weapons to hack and slash your way through this giant open world. If you can look past the goofy stuff, this is a real gem!

This is one of my favorite Adventure Role Play games. Good mechanics, controls, and story. I have played it for a long time and still come back to it regularly.

I enjoyed playing this game. It is older, it is not top notch AAA modern looking RPG but it is still good imho. 

First 2 to 4 hours are slow. You are nothing and everything can kill you easily. Even a single wolf! I believe that most players stop playing during these first 4 hours. But when you overcome the beginning you propably will like the game if you like open world RPGs.

Pros:

+ The game world is huge and open. You can go wherever you want.
+ You can build your character freely. But there is some more stronger and weaker builds.
+ Many very good looking armors and weapons.
+ Music mix is very good.
+ Character progression and combination of armors and weapons to make them better is fantastic.
+ Incredible amount of stuff you can loot from your enemies.

Neutral:

+/- Quests and the main storyline is just mediocre.
+/- I liked the combat system but it can be clunky and I can imagine that many players are not going to like it.
+/- Magic looks amazing. Spells are good but not well balanced. Some are very weak, some are overpowered.
+/- I find the voice acting in some ways good and funny but the quality was sometimes bad. I know that many players have criticized the voice acting in the game but in my opinion it was not so bad. Compare it to the TES IV which is a game with much bigger budget and the voice acting in this game was made by only a couple actors (5 or so?). Remember, this is not a multimillion AAA game.

Cons:

- Weaker optimalization (I got some fps drops when many npcs where around)
- The end of the main story was rushed for sure.
- Cutscenes are very low quality.
- Horses! OMG, Riding was okish, but I kept loosing my horse. They kept dying or just disapearing. The function to call a horse has never been functional. 

It is an older game which is in some ways similar to the Elder Scrolls IV Oblivion. It looks like a cheaper version of that game. BUT I really liked the game and I can recommend it for everyone who likes that kind of games.

[h1]"Be you a-wantin' something?"[/h1]
In response to that question - "Be you a-wantin' [strike]something[/strike] Two Worlds: Epic Edition?" (which, might I add, has terribly bad voice acting) - I say "No. No, I do not want Two Worlds: Epic Edition, and I recommend that all who consider this question stay far away from the game." 
"Oh," replies the humble Medieval guard. "Why?" 
Well, simply: [i]Two Worlds[/i] is not a good game. It has a lifeless, unengaging opening, (ooh, those awful Groms!) the characters are hardly engaging, the world is flat and boring, the combat terribly dry - it is the antithesis, I find, of a good RPG. When searching for an RPG, I find the opening hours to be make or break, especially in a genre that is so demanding of one's time. If the opening is not sufficiently written or well-paced to make you care about the tasks you will be performing for the next fifty hours, then the game feels like an exercise in futility. In [i]The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion[/i], one is made to care about the fate of the world because the survival of the Empire hinges on you. Or the exploration of that ruin - it hinges on you. 
Whereas in [i]Two Worlds[/i], the world didn't give a crap about me. And not in a good, Pathologic-esque way. [i]Two Worlds[/i] just didn't seem to care what I did, what I chose, where I went. I decided to go for a run in the game you see, on my third and final attempt to crack what others have described as a worthwhile endeavour. So, off I went, my oddly proportioned He-Man character sauntering through the wilderness. I stopped to fight some local mooks, but my health was drawing low. I figured I should probably try to run, as I didn't want to reload an earlier save. It turns out that my character was many times faster than any enemy. So off I ran - I was like some hapless version of The Flash, attracting boars, wolves and local orcs to try wallop me, but none could catch me. For a time, it was strangely entertaining, I must admit. It's one of those moments that is self-generated, and the moments that so many developers hinge the success of their game on. "It's a Radiant world," claimed Bethesda Softworks about [i]Skyrim[/i]. Like hell it was, really. But at least it was better than Two Worlds' effort. Bethesda are famously restrictive when it comes to this: their NPCs being essential so you can't go off their predesignated rails. Two Worlds seemed even more restrictive. I tried to cause a little mayhem - as you do in medieval fantasy RPGs, having saved - and found that a humble peasant was able to curbstomp me in a single pithy slap. Down I went, a sack of potatoes in the mud, and I thought: does this game value me as a player? Does [i]Two Worlds[/i] care that I am putting in effort?
[i]Pathologic[/i] beats the hell out of you. It beats you until you are a bloody stain on the sidewalk and still it tries to wash you away with a hose. But in spite of all of that, [i]Pathologic[/i] respects you. You invest in [i]Pathologic[/i] and [i]Pathologic[/i] invests in you. 
I have tried three separate times in as many years to crack the elusive appeal of [i]Two Worlds[/i]. And once again, perhaps, it has beaten me. Perhaps I am just not the person for whom this game was made. But I see no appeal in this game, for it does not respect the time I have attempted to put into it, those three logged hours concealing even more offline hours beneath the hood. Farewell, [i]Two Worlds.[/i]. You shall be relegated to a dusty box titled: "Games I Really, Honestly Tried".

Ну...Сразу говорю: Игра-Хуита. Начну с того что это считай копирка Готики и ТЕS:3. НО естественно не вплане сюжета.
Это сложноватая игра, расчитаная на игроков которые играли в Готику например.В плане реализации если честно игра очень и очень слаба. Геймплей не всегда удобный не то что хорошый, на счет графики писать не буду скажу то что для 2009 могло быть и лучше. Квесты скучные. Вообщем не рекомендую п.с(Хорошо что по скидке купил за 10 грн, а то хуита редкостная).

This game is EPIC
Do you want to ride an ORC HORSE up a cliff and over dunes while duel wielding swords to slay a dragon? YOU GOT IT. 
DO you want a shield that's made from the face of a dragon? 
Do you want to play with swords that exist irl? 
How does running around Sand dunes, to bamboo forests, to hell on earth itself back to snow drift filled mountain slopes to cursed tombs and dungeons to castle streets to war torn battlefields and back to beaches and islands through rivers and forests sound to you? 
This game has it all and so much more its not even limited to swords and sorcery, there’s archery, sneak attacks with daggers, and more.
ALSO!
No Random Invisible walls.
Like as if that were some sort of huge bonus but hey these days it kinda is.
How does this sound:
You have the ability to kill everything and everyone in the game, you have real freedom to choose who lives and who dies in this game, someone ticks you off, dude you can kill em.
How about vendors having unlimited gold?
Or How about every house you can enter is filled with things to loot which are all filled with random leveled loot. You can enter a house and find straight up spells, plate mail, diamonds whatever.
Okay lets get real here for a second.
Without any training whatsoever, you can combine any item with another duplicate item to make a more powerful version of that item, rings, armor weapons its all able to be upgraded automatically with another compatible version of that item.
Alchemy, potions with permanent effects?! That you can make as many as you can find ingredients for?! How about the fact that you can add elemental damage to any weapon? And you can make these elemental damage adders with your brewing pot which by the way just exists inside your inventory at all times?! 
Did I mention ghosts appear every night all over the map and you can kill them?
How about the fact that you can wear 4 rings at a time? Which can have insane effects.
How about the almost dozens of armors in the game how about the fact that this game is so indepth it has a RPG manual for irl play.
Lemme just break this down right quick.
This game has some of the most epic environmental animations out there, the player character model is gorgeous for its time and holds up to today and the combat, IS EPIC.
How does duel wielding two swords while casting spells to summon demons then golems then casting fireballs then running over to chop some enemies up sound? And all that without even breaking to open an inventory or switch what you’re holding in your hands this game is the best and I can’t wait for more from this franchise.

Look, this game is the definition of euro jank rpg. That is what makes it an amazing game. If you like games where you can abuse the hell out of the vanilla mechanics and become completely overpowered before the quarter point of the game, you will love this game. Ignore the story, abuse the mechanics and just enjoy it. Looks like my inlaws.

Unos de mis juegos de infancia fue pero tiene muchos defectos y puntos que no se aprovecharon bien en el juego. Desde mi punto de vista es un juego MUY DESPERDICIADO.

-Tiene una historia buena con sus trasfondos. Ademas algunas misiones secundarias pudieron tener mas profundidad como por ejem la misión del pueblo abandonado pudo tener un desarrollo bueno, pero no.
-Su interfaz es muy incompleto pero la Alquimia esta decente (fácil de usarla y de crear pociones). 
-La pestaña de habilidades es muy simple y sencilla muy bueno, y la manera de aprender las habilidades es muy ingenioso pero muy fácil de encontrar los maestros.
-Los movimientos son muy sencillos y toscos una forma de decir es "Con la Q esquivo todo" no importa si estas rodeado y los bugs no son muy lindo que digamos hay momentos que son divertidos pero un bug es un bug ademas el la montura es muy difícil de usar
-El mapa es "algo" grande y muy difícil de descubrir el mapa pero los puntos de colores son fáciles de entender (El rojo es un objetivo que tenemos que eliminar, el azul es Ir a X lugar). 
-Y la pestaña de reputación no es lo que digamos muy útil, pero si es útil la reputación de mercaderes 
-La cantidad de monstruos es variable y compensa con algunas cosas malas pero lo malo es que hay mas mazmorras de esqueletos que de otros monstruos es casi como pelea con orcos y esqueletos solo
-la cantidad de hechizos es abundante y entretenido como para estar un buen rato bien que hechizo es mejor pero se pueden usar uno sobre otro no importa si estas en pelear al tocar el menú de hechizos el juego se pone en pausa

Es triste que un juego pudo ser unos de los mejores de su época. Pero no lo fue solo porque los desarrolladores no lo aprovecharon su potencial. Triste, Muy triste todo
Le doy un 6.5 de 10

Two Worlds is underrated. A lot of people rag on the game, but pay attention to who's doing the ragging -- generally young or new gamers who haven't played many RPGs and whose expectations for games are based on the AAA fashions of the last 5-10 years. Anyone serious about RPGs or adventure games or open world games would do well to play this one through. 

It isn't as polished as the better-known games that came out when it did, but its only real flaws are technical and superficial -- lower quality graphics than others from 2007, clunky controls, mediocre voice acting (which is irrelevant, and not the kind of thing anyone should care about, but people piss and moan about this like it's a game-breaker), and some bugs that were either never fixed, or are due to playing the game on modern OS, such as all the cut scenes being absent from the game. But there are no issues with gameplay or performance, or bugs that impact progression or the overall experience. 

These problems aside, it's worth looking at everything that's good about the game.  

The story is a decent if somewhat generic one, but it only serves to give purpose and background to what is a pretty outstanding adventure, a very good open world, quality character progression, and dozens of enjoyable side quests that will take you all across the fantasy world of Antaloor. Where the game really shines is in its openness and nonlinearity, its freedom, its RPG mechanics and gameplay. The player is free to explore a vast and diverse world as they wish, at whatever pace they wish, and to visit locales in any order they wish, giving plenty of room to approach quests in any order and to pursue any outcome that seems relevant. 

Teleporters and horses make travel easier, but it's good to veer off the beaten path to see what mysteries and dangers lurk in the woods or out in the desert or beneath some ruins or atop a tower, or within the walls of a city. World design is thought out and feels alive. The map's fog of war is well done, in that it only clears the space directly around the character, giving you a better idea of where you have and haven't been. After hours in the game, instead of having large chunks of the map cleared of the fog, you'll only see your path cleared, showing you precisely where you have and haven't been, not just a general idea. To have areas revealed in detail will require you to physically go there, and the path you take will also become unveiled as you travel it.

 Many secrets await in those undiscovered regions. The dangers one will encounter cover all sorts of high fantasy staples, from bandits and warriors and assassins and mages to skeletons and undead and golems and dragons and necromancers and orcs and various types of demons, populating all sorts of locations that are also staples of high fantasy: deep, hilly forests, grasslands, deserts, dungeons and caves, temples, ruins. 

Leveling and skills and items allow one to make their character unique, with a great variety of attributes and abilities to learn or master, a classless leveling system open to any mish-mash of abilities one wishes, customizable weapons and armor, alchemy to perform, locks to pick, traps to set, seemingly endless spells from 5 or 6 different schools of magic, and six factions across the world with whom to build reputations and undertake work for. 

Combat is mechanically simple, but with the variety of weapons and spells it's always full of action and a sense of excitement. The way you approach a fight is up to you. Even the summoning spells are full of variety, with something like 10 different creatures to summon to your aid. The list of offensive and buff spells is too long to mention. The cool thing about the spells is that they work through magical cards you discover through the world. And the more cards of the same spell you find, the higher you stack that deck and the more powerful and effective that spell becomes. This is one of many ways that exploration directly benefits the player. 

There are a lot of items to use and potions or other helpful things to craft through alchemy, treasures and other valuables to steal or hunt down, and a whole bunch of immersion-creating factors that go into Two Worlds to make it consistently interesting.

Think of it as an Oblivion-esque game on a lower budget and a less focused main quest. Despite the inferior technology and the worse voice acting and simpler gameplay, many of the defining factors of good RPG design are here.

oddly addicting game, very fun too level up and increase your weapon and armor stats as you combine them together, i mean the animations/voice acting and even quest programming are kinda shit, but the games still pretty fun... once you unlock fast travel at least.
Entertainment for hours on end.

Wow. I own the physical Collector's Edition of this game way back from its release, but never got past the opening few hours. As a young lad I suppose it was just a bit too challenging for me initially. I came back to it on steam a few years ago and had a grand old time, about until I had to cross the river dividing the map when I bounced off it again. Now I've come back to it, and finally completed this game that's followed me for over ten years. I... don't recommend it.

There's a lot to like about this game at first glance; there is a fleshed-out magic system, with five separate elemental schools and spells that can be altered with additional effects. Spells or their modifiers can be stacked for effect, with three spells in your bar at one time and three modifications per spell. The downside is that spells are found as quest rewards or as loot; I finished the game without finding every spell. Unfortunately, the magic isn't very useful beyond healing spells, buffing spells, the defensive shield spells, and the summon spells. I dumped over a hundred points into willpower and it was never as good as dumping those points into the other stats; the magic spells just didn't keep up in damage with close combat. I recommend getting a decent summon and getting however many points are required to use it and your shield spell of choice, then ditching the willpower stat entirely. 

Each weapon type has an associated active skill (or in the case of the bow, multiple active skills) and there are a number of toggleable passive skills including a defensive mode, sneak mode and berserk mode. Bows are pretty garbage until late game and are expensive to train for, and finding a bludgeoning arrow is pure luck so the average player will probably go with the close combat. Melee combat is mostly an affair of backsteps and mashing the left mouse button. Enemies have different resistances, so a piercing or slashing weapon won't do much to skeletons. Attacking from horseback yields a damage bonus, and the horses shy away from enemies or cliffs which is a neat touch. There's a decent variety of traps, and a weapon upgrade system involving application of elemental stones and combination of duplicate weapons for significant damage bonuses. There's also a robust alchemy system which allows you to combine reagants to give your character temporary and permanent stat boosts, also giving you something to do while traversing the world by harvesting herbs. Overall the game's systems appear sufficiently deep and complex to sustain a joyous romp across the mostly generic fantasy world. They don't.

The problems with the game aren't immediately apparent; the northern half of the map introduces the player to all of the game's main factions (There is a faction reputation system; no, it doesn't matter. I had maximum reputation with all the factions at the end of the game except the initial two karga/noble factions) and there are a good number of quests in all the towns as you ride around slaying orcs and running errands. This top portion of the map seems to be where most of the development time went, because after completing a quest to get some orc disguise armor and heading south over the river things began to fall apart. Each main area you arrive at from now until the end of the game will have a handful of quests, and that's it. Each area with quests is clearly visible on the map, so there's no reason to explore the wilderness. There are interesting biomes in this southern section, but no reason to really linger or explore in any of them. By now you should already have some of the best weapons and armor in the game if you have been the least bit diligent, and you should already have bought all the skills you need, so you don't even need money anymore. At least you can ignore the slow, painful process of plopping down a teleporter, grabbing everything you can carry, teleporting to town, selling it all, and teleporting back to do it all again. Which, by the way, is the process you are expected to undergo with every encounter throughout the game. For reference, from the time I crossed the river to the end of the game took me six hours. All you do is go to each main area, do your main/side quests, then enter the final quest string where you get a sharp difficulty spike and make your ending choice.

To cap everything off, the game did not run well for me. I found a lot of bugs during my playtime and had some very unfortunately timed crashes. Quests didn't update, world states didn't refresh, and neither ending cutscene would play for me when I finished the game; I just got booted to the main menu. So I watched them on youtube. They were short and really not worth it. I liked the first 10 hours of this game in spite of the jank; there's a lot of good ideas in here. There's just not enough to account for the meaningless slog the game becomes in its latter half.

A flawed masterpiece of an RPG. The game is far from perfect, but it's become one of my favourite in it's genre for it'd deep roleplaying and customisation options, interesting world and lore, the level of freedom that you have in the world and your character build, and it's horrible but narm-charmy voice acting, which is just a blast to listen to and laugh at. So if you're a fan of RPG's like Elder Scrolls or Gothic, I'd highly recommend you give this a go.

Two worlds is a hidden gem in my experience, yes the game maybe dated but it has some really nice features in it, for example if you want to upgrade your weapon just find another weapon of the same type and combine the two simple! The magic is very good simple to use, just a joy to play.
The story is a bit generic but it really doesn't matter because there are some really good quests in the game anyway, so if you are feeling for some good quality "Euro Jank" e.g. Risen, Elex that sort of thing then this is the game for you!

Pros:
1.Visual is amazing, better than Gta Vice city and Jedi academy, slightly less than Star wars/Lord of the Ring Online.
2. Good Variety of Enemies, Peaceful npcs, quests. 
3. Good looking world map. 
4. very low price

Cons:
1. terrible combat system, only 1 animation (for all melee weapons) and it dont even make sence, 1 melee forms of stunning. No extra techniques, no stun lock, no special, no martial art sword style.
2. The Quest Display log is tiny and unclear, you dont even know what quest are disable at time.
3. The alchemy systems are in alpha stage, what ever you put in that pot, it's always gives you a potion.
4. The Freaking horse.
5. Enemy Level Plot armour, differents damage types are not finished.

Overall: It's an Unfinished game.

Truly "The Room" of video games. This is the best worst game I've ever played and it's given me hours of entertainment both on console and PC. I recommend buying it and giving it a playthrough, you'll have a great time laughing at the awkward not-quite-old english, the janky animations, and the absurd quests. Hell even the weapon names are a laugh. It was well worth the 5 dollars I paid. Plus it gives trading cards.

I used to play this game way back when it first released on Xbox 360, and I must say I had a blast. While I was too young to really understand a lot of things, the amount of freedom the game granted was enough to make me never stop playing. Unfortunately back then my game was given away at a yard sale, and up till now I haven't had the chance to play it again. So I must say one thing. Don't pass up a game just because it's a little dated, this game is worth a try.
RPG, Open World and, by now, a well deserved place among the classics. Need i say more?

Игра - один из добротных представителей старых RPG. Игру можно сравнить с Готикой 3, но во многих аспектах более совершенна. Графика лучше, боёвка интересней, Есть такие механики, как езда на лошади, плавание, которые можно прокачивать.Сюжет добротный, плавно переходящий из первой части во вторую. Из классов можно играть не только за классических магов, воров, мечников. Есть довольно сбалансированные их подклассы. Система крафта приятно удивила: здесь нету определённого списка зелий, бомб и кристаллов-усилителей. Тут тебе дают ингредиенты, которые ты совмещаешь, добиваясь разных итогов. Данной теме отдаётся немалая часть на форумах, если не варить типовые зелья. Подведя итоги - игра МНЕ очень сильно понравилась.

I remember sinking hundreds and hundreds of hours into this strange little game back in 2009-2010. It's not very polished and it's not exactly an "A" title either. It's kind of like a poor man's Gothic. Still - the nostalgia in playing it today brings back those good memories of a decade ago. To this day - 2W's is still an addictive, interesting and absorbing RPG to play. If you haven't played it and you like classic RPG's - you're missing out on a true gem - just don't expect Gothic or Skyrim.
